docs.snippet: The Most Rev. Helder Camara is called the "Red Bishop" because he fights for social justice in Brazil's impoverished northeast, criticizes military dictatorships in his own and other countries, and often supports radical reform causes in Latin...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Most Rev. Helder Camara is called the "Red Bishop" because he fights for social justice in Brazil's impoverished northeast, criticizes military dictatorships in his own and other countries, and often supports radical reform causes in Latin America.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Aug.19 The new blue car cruising in northwest Washington carried no printed legend but had seven large red lights on its roof, an extra radio antenna and a special license plate. Inside were two officers wearing sunglasses and with gold...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug.19 The new blue car cruising in northwest Washington carried no printed legend but had seven large red lights on its roof, an extra radio antenna and a special license plate. Inside were two officers wearing sunglasses and with gold braid on the right shoulder of their white shirts. I

docs.snippet: Hopes are high for an increase in wool consumption throughout the world as a result of stepped-up research and marketing programs, A.C.B. Maiden, managing director of the International Wool Secretariat, said in an interview yesterday.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hopes are high for an increase in wool consumption throughout the world as a result of stepped-up research and marketing programs, A.C.B. Maiden, managing director of the International Wool Secretariat, said in an interview yesterday.
docs.abstract: Internatl Wool Secretariat managing dir Maiden expresses hope for increase in wool consumption throughout world as result of stepped-up research and mktg programs, int; efforts of Wool Secretariat in spurring research noted; illus; wool consumption in '69 was 3.5-billion pounds, little changed from '68

headline.main: Wool Growers Pin Hopes on Improved Marketing; Producers of Wool Pin Hopes To Improved Marketing Plans

docs.snippet: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 22-- Through television and the press, Fidel Castro is effectively stumping in Chile for the election of a Marxist president on Sept.4.
docs.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 22-- Through television and the press, Fidel Castro is effectively stumping in Chile for the election of a Marxist president on Sept.4.
docs.abstract: Premier Castro campaigns for Allende on TV and in leftist press; seen improving own and Marxists' image; polls indicate close race, giving Allende good chance of winning; leftward trends of Chilean pol thought and spread of anti-US feeling create favorable situation; campaign revd; Castro remarks stress need to keep Chile from becoming imperialist base against Peru and vice versa; Allende promises to maintain democracy and to nationalize foreign business, especially Amer, and major local monopolies; opponents exploit his friendship with Cuba

headline.main: Castro, on TV, Aids Marxist Candidate in Chile's Sept. 4 Presidential Election; Presidential Race Is Close A Democracy Since 1932 Congress Expected to Decide

byline.original: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 24 (AP) The Tupamaro guerrilla group broke a silence of 13 days by announcing today that its two foreign hostages were in good health and had not been "sentenced."
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 24 (AP) The Tupamaro guerrilla group broke a silence of 13 days by announcing today that its two foreign hostages were in good health and had not been "sentenced."
docs.abstract: Tupamaros say hostages are well and will not be sentenced while police hold Tupamaros in prison, message to news media; announce renewed campaign against Govt forces and US advisers

headline.main: URUGUAY REBELS SAY CAPTIVES ARE WELL

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 25 (UPI) Five Tupamaros guerrillas, members of the organization that is holding an American and a Brazilian as hostages, raided a radio station here today, set off a bomb and fled.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 25 (UPI) Five Tupamaros guerrillas, members of the organization that is holding an American and a Brazilian as hostages, raided a radio station here today, set off a bomb and fled.
docs.abstract: 5 guerrillas raid Montevideo radio station, set off bomb, and flee; damage is undetermined; another guerilla group recently took over different station for 10 mins

headline.main: Guerrillas in Montevideo Bomb a Radio Station

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 31 (UPI) Men believed to be members of the Tupamaro guerrilla movement opened fire from a speeding car on an army training school in downtown Montevideo today and security guards returned the fire. No one was reported...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 31 (UPI) Men believed to be members of the Tupamaro guerrilla movement opened fire from a speeding car on an army training school in downtown Montevideo today and security guards returned the fire. No one was reported wounded.
docs.abstract: OAS meets, Rio, to find new ways of dealing with pol kidnappings

headline.main: Guerrillas and Guard Units Exchange Fire in Uruguay
